attributes.comment:
The proposed fee increase is disappointing, particularly for a couple currently
engaged in the adoption process. The transient nature of my military career
makes it nearly impossible to engage in domestic adoption. Even if that were not
the case, the current state of family law in the United States (permitting and
sometimes encouraging birth parents to reclaim the children they gave up for
adoption) creates an uncertainty that, in my opinion, makes domestic adoption
untenable.

1. The information provided is insufficient to allow for full analysis and useful
criticism. For example, Section X of the proposal "cherry-picks" examples of
significantly increased completion rates (comparing the current review to the FY08
review). Only six forms and the waiver reviews are cited, despite the significant,
nearly across-the-board fee increases. Table 11 claims that $72 is required from
each I-600/600A petition to cover the cost of free services to asylum seekers and
those individuals granted fee waivers. Other than the word of the agency, no
information was provided to support these figures that appear unreasonable
without explanation. Section I claimed that certain supporting documentation (the
FY 2008/2009 Fee Review Supporting Documentation and Small Entity Analysis
for Adjustment of the Immigration Benefit Application/Petition Fee Schedule)
would be in the electronic docket, yet the electronic docket lists no such
information. Only document USCIS-2006-0044-0001 (the notice of proposed
rulemaking) is government information. The remainder is public comment. This
failure to provide sufficient (and promised) factual detail and rationale interferes
with my ability to comment meaningfully on this point. I am unable to compare the
current completion rates with the previous completion rates and evaluate the
claims made by the agency with regard to the impact of longer completion rates
on most of the forms with proposed fee increases.

2. Based on the current completion rates, I have significant concerns regarding
waste in the department. For instance, the completion rate for the I-600/600A is
1.53 hours in the local office. The agency proposes to charge $670 for 1.53 hours.
Even removing the costs not associated with the determination ($140 from Table
10, plus $72 from Table 11), that leaves $458 for that hour and a half of work. If
this a reasonable amount, then I work for the wrong federal agency. I note that in
Section VI.A., the agency claims that 39% of the FY 2008/2009 IEFA costs are
attributable to overhead. Recalling the agency?s definition of overhead (?the
ongoing administrative expenses of a business which cannot be attributed to any
specific business activity, but are still necessary for the business to function?),
over a third of the costs cannot be attributed to any specific activity. This is an
opportunity for profligate behavior. If such wild inefficiency were eliminated, fee
increases might be more reasonable.

3. The legal authority for this action, 8 U.S.C. 1356(m), according to Section II,
permits, but does not require, the proposed fees. To quote the statute, ?[F]ees for
providing adjudication and naturalization services *may* be set at a level that will
ensure recovery of the full costs of providing all such services, including the costs
of similar services provided without charge to asylum applicants or other
immigrants. Such fees *may* also be set at a level that will recover any additional
costs associated with the administration of the fees collected.? Emphasis added.
It appears that the federal government is providing essential government services
on a fee basis and using the justification that these forms are all ?voluntary.? See
Section XII.B. Voting is voluntary, yet poll taxes are illegal, even for ballots printed
in multiple languages, despite the fact that all naturalized citizens are required to
pass a civics test in English to become citizens. Making a family whole and
insuring that all members of that family are citizens is no less critical to this
nation?s well-being than insuring that non-English speakers are able to vote.

4. While I concur in large part with the proposal to limit fee waivers to only a few
forms, I believe the number of forms is too limited. Companies seeking to admit a
foreign employee or individuals seeking status based on substantial investments
are rational limitations, but limitations on many other situations are unreasonable.
While I understand the drive to avoid having immigrants become ?public charges,? I
find great irony as I think of the words on the Statue of Liberty: ?Give me your
tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free, the wretched
refuse of your teeming shore. Send these, the homeless, tempest-tost [sic] to
me...?

5. While not caused by the agency or the federal government, international
adoptions are a lengthy process. Couples seeking foreign adoptions must often
file additional forms and have additional fingerprints taken as the existing time
frames are unreasonable for some countries. These ?renewals? have been reviewed
once already, and thus should not be as time-consuming as an initial application.
The agency should give consideration to decreasing the fees for such renewals.

Thank you for your consideration of these comments, and I hope that the factual
basis for the proposed rule is made available so that future comments may be
more meaningful.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by David Bargatze
